data.title: Avoid passing paths outside of repository to git status subprocesses
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/tree-view/issues/906

This fixes an issue refreshing repository statuses with an Atom project containing multiple folders. We collect all project paths belonging to the current repository by relativizing them against its working directory. Unfortunately, when `Repository.relativize` is passed an absolute path that is not relative to the repository's working directory, it just returns the path unchanged. We were passing this absolute path into the subprocess that collected statuses, and since it was outside the repository in question we were returning no status changes for it, thus clearing all statuses for the repository.

This fixes the problem by ensuring we include no absolute paths in the collection of paths we pass to the subprocess.

data.title: Unobtrusive uncaught exceptions
data.body:
Related https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6945

Although it was incredibly helpful while Atom was still in beta, I think we should reconsider popping up big red notifications for every uncaught exception. 

Admittedly, doing this provides us with a vast pool of users catching our bugs, allowing us to hone in on code paths that might not be working the way we expect. However, I strongly suspect (from almost 2 years of issue triage experience) that it gives users the sense that Atom is wildly unstable.

This can be exacerbated by Atom's hackability – since a package can literally do anything, there is nothing preventing a community package from completely disrupting a user's workflow by throwing exceptions left and right (and this isn't hypothetical, either – there are definitely some packages well known for making Atom "feel" unstable). This also increases our issue triage burden, because we often get reports of issues that are ultimately caused by community packages.

Compare this with any other production desktop app – how many of them burden their users with taking action on mere uncaught exceptions? With the exception of hard crashes, there's no reason why any of these necessarily should require manual user action.

I think users on Atom's stable channel reasonably expect Atom to feel, err, stable 😆 , and we should do all that we can to make their lives simpler, more pleasant, and more productive. Beta users, on the other hand, have explicitly opted-in to testing a more experimental, potentially unstable Atom.
## Proposal 🎉

On the `stable` channel, just log uncaught exceptions silently instead of popping up a notification (and send to Bugsnag, if they've opted-in to telemetry). On `beta`, keep the current behavior, but in addition to this revamped logging.

Persist these logs to disk and provide a command to open issues with those logs attached.
## Considerations 💭
1. We would lose a large sample set for discovering uncaught exceptions – what if we miss some?
2. Uncaught exceptions and stack traces in themselves are rarely, if ever, enough information to properly diagnose a bug. This is why the notifications package currently attaches the most recent commands entered, the user's config, and their installed packages, and encourages users to describe reproduction steps. How would we get the information we need to debug uncaught exceptions without making users open issues on GitHub for them?
3. Packages might be explicitly using the `atom.notifications` API to pop open errors, even though it's still private. Should we prevent this in the stable channel (but only for error-type notifications)?
### Potential Solutions 🚀
1. This shouldn't matter – our beta channel exists for this exact purpose. We shouldn't treat users on stable like beta users.
2. We should set up robust logs for all registered Atom commands, and persist these logs to disk. (cf. https://github.com/winstonjs/winston).

What do you think? :eyes: @iolsen @lee-dohm @atom/feedback

data.title: Upgrade electron to fix canvas bug
data.body:
### Description

When switching spaces on OS X, `<canvas>` elements in the editor view sometimes disappear (i.e. turn completely white). This is most likely related to this Chromium bug: [https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=588434](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=588434). This bug is fixed in newer versions of Chromium. This could be fixed by upgrading electron.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Use a plugin which places a canvas in the editor view.
2. Launch atom, switch spaces on OS X, switch back.
3. Try this a few times if the bug doesn't occur right away.

**Expected behavior:** the canvas should still be there when you switch spaces back.

**Actual behavior:** the canvas is rendered as a white element, no matter what `background-color` it is given, and no matter what CSS transformations are applied to it.

**EDIT:** it was white in my editor because I use a white theme. The canvas appears to become a solid color that matches the editor's background color (probably takes the pixel buffer from the thing behind it). I know it's not just transparent, because I can move the canvas above the text and the text is clearly covered by something of a solid color.
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.9.4
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

Note how old that version of Chrome and Electron are. The [Chromium bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=588434) I linked above was present in Chrome 49. Thus, electron should be upgraded.
